Photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction is an attractive way to alleviate the current energy crisis, but it is important to prepare catalysts with efficient catalytic capacity. In this work, Prussian blue analogs were firstly prepared, and then calcined to obtain porous transition metal (Ni, Co, Fe) oxides (TMOs). The metal composition of catalysts has great influences on their structures and catalytic properties. Among them, NCF-TMO catalyst shows excellent photothermal catalytic performance, and can produce 2.9 mmol g-1 h-1 CO and 1.6 mmol g-1 h-1 mmol CH4 at low CO2 and H2 concentrations. For the NCF-TMO, its superior catalytic performance mainly benefitted from two reasons: (1) The construction of heterojunction between NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3, which promotes the efficient dynamic processes of charge carriers; (2) The formation of abundant surface reactive active sites facilitates the efficient conversion of CO2 molecules. This study offers a bright direction for the resource utilization of CO2. Graphical Abstract The interaction between NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3 dramatically enhanced the photothermal catalytic reduction of CO2 to CO and CH4. ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Photothermal catalysis Transition metal oxides Heterojunction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to human activities, atmospheric CO2 concentration has increased year by year, causing a series of global climate and environmental problems [1–4]. From another point of view, if CO2 is treated by catalytic hydrogenation, it can not only reduce the content of greenhouse gas, but also convert CO2 into high value-added chemical products, which has important strategic significance [5–8]. However, the chemical structure of CO2 is stable, and the direct cleavage of the CO bond requires overcoming a large reaction energy barrier [9]. Therefore, it needs to be carried out with the participation of catalysts. Recently, photothermal catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to produce CO and CH4 is a hot research topic [10–13]. Among them, the reaction of CO2 hydrogenation into CO is called "reverse water gas shift" (referred to as RWGS), and its corresponding reaction equation is: CO2+H2→CO+H2O ∆ H 298 K 0 = + 41.17 KJ ∙ mol − 1 [14,15]. From the perspective of energy, the RWGS reaction is endothermic, and increasing the temperature is conducive to the equilibrium reaction moving forward [16]. However, the catalytic reaction at high temperature faces the disadvantages of high energy consumption and easy deactivation of catalysts. On the other hand, the reaction of CO2 hydrogenation into CH4 (generally called "Sabatier reaction") is exothermic, and its corresponding reaction equation is: CO2+4H2→CH4+2H2O ∆ H 298 K 0 = − 165 KJ ∙ mol − 1 , the increase of the reaction temperature is not conducive to the formation of CH4 [17]. From the perspective of thermodynamics, the reaction of CH4 generation is suitable for low temperature, but from the perspective of kinetics, low temperature will reduce the reaction rate [18]. Based on the above analysis, if CO and CH4 are to be produced simultaneously through CO2 hydrogenation, the catalysts are needed to regulate the above two reactions. At present, most catalysts studied on CO2 hydrogenation are divided into three categories: supported metal catalysts, metal oxide composites, and transition metal carbides. The first type of catalysts includes supported precious and non-precious metal catalysts (such as Cu/SiO2 [19], Rh/TiO2 [20], Pd/Al2O3 [21], Co/CeO2 [22], etc.). Although noble metal catalysts have good activity in CO2 hydrogenation, their application is limited due to their scarce content and high price [23–25]. Non-precious metals are abundant, but they still have disadvantages, such as poor high-temperature stability, easy sintering, and deactivation [26–28]. The second type of catalysts is metal oxide composites, which have the disadvantage of poor structural stability, because they are easy to be reduced to metal by hydrogen in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. For example, Park et al. reported that the conversion rate of CO2 decreased from 43 % to 17 % using ZnO/Al2O3 composite after a reaction at 600 °C for 48 h [29]. This is mainly due to the deactivation of the catalyst caused by the reduction of ZnO to Zn during the reaction. The transition metal carbides are also CO2 hydrogenation catalysts discovered in recent years [30,31]. The electronic properties of transition metals are changed after the introduction of carbon element, making them similar to noble metal catalysts, thus exhibiting high activity in CO2 hydrogenation reaction. For example, Mo2C, as an excellent catalyst, has strong H2 dissociation and CO bond-breaking ability [32]. However, transition metal carbides are not suitable for large-scale application due to their high oxygen affinity, which lead to the reaction of transition metal carbides with CO2 and evolution into transition metal oxides during the catalytic reaction process. In order to avoid these drawbacks of the above-mentioned various catalysts, we found that the derivatives of Prussian blue analogs (PBAs) can be well used in photothermal synergistic catalytic reduction of CO2. Prussian blue and PBAs are a group of transition metal cyanides with an open skeleton structure [33]. The general chemical formula of PBAs is M1 II[M2 III(CN)6]2·H2O, where M1 and M2 are transition metal ions [34]. In the PBAs structure, M1 and M2 cations are connected to each other through M2-CN-M1 bonds, M1 coordinates with the N atoms on six adjacent CN ligands, and M2 coordinates with C atoms on adjacent CN ligands to form a three-position open skeleton with a large number of gap sites, thus possessing unique structural stability and chemical activity [35]. In recent years, PBAs have been widely applied to supercapacitors [36,37], electrocatalysis [38,39], and lithium batteries, because of their excellent catalytic and electrochemical properties [40,41]. For example, Yang et al. synthesized metal oxide (NiFe2O4-NiO) based on PBAs for supercapacitors, and the experimental results showed that this material not only reduces the charge transfer impedance, but also enhances the pseudo-capacitance [42]. However, until now, there have been no reports on PBAs derivatives in the photothermal catalytic reduction of CO2. In this work, we prepared three Ni3[Co0.5Fe0.5(CN)6]2-PBA, Ni3[Co(CN)6]2-PBA, and Ni3[Fe(CN)6]2-PBA nanocubes by chemical co-precipitation at room temperature, respectively, and then calcined these PBAs in the air to prepare transition metal oxides (TMOs) based on PBAs: Ni-Co-Fe-TMO, Ni-Co-TMO, Ni-Fe-TMO. The characterization results show that the three oxides not only retain the stable three-dimensional open skeleton structure and active sites of PBAs, but also make metal oxides contact closely to form heterojunctions. These structural advantages promote the full contact between the catalyst and CO2 molecules and the interfacial transport of carriers between heterojunctions, thus showing the unique performance of photothermal catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to produce CO and CH4. The activity evaluation results showed that compared with Ni-Co-TMO and Ni-Fe-TMO, Ni-Co-Fe-TMO exhibits much better photothermal catalytic reduction of CO2 hydrogenation to produce CO and CH4. Besides, Ni-Co-Fe-TMO also displayed superior long-term photothermal catalytic stability (over 12 h). Based on the above research results, we sincerely hope that this work can facilitate the rational design of PBAs-based catalysts, meanwhile, provide a reference for realizing the photothermal catalytic reduction of CO2 into high-value-added chemicals. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemical reagents used here were obtained from Aladdin Chemical Reagents Co., Ltd. Deionized water with an electrical conductivity of 0.055 μS/cm was used in the whole experiment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation As shown in Scheme 1, these catalysts were fabricated by a three-step treatment. Taking Ni-Co-Fe-TMO as an example, the specific synthesis method can be described as follows: (1) Potassium citrate (C6H5K3O7, 9 mmol) and Nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O, 6 mmol) were added to 200 mL deionized water as solution A. Meanwhile, potassium hexacyanoferrate (K3[Fe(CN)6], 2 mmol) and potassium hexacyanocobaltate (K3[Co(CN)6], 2 mmol) were dissolved into the other 200 mL deionized water as solution B. Then, the two solutions were mixed evenly by magnetic agitation. (2) After standing for 12 h, the mixture was filtered and washed to obtain Ni3[Co0.5Fe0.5(CN)6]2-PBA precursor with a solid nanocubic structure. (3) The Ni3[Co0.5Fe0.5(CN)6]2-PBA precursor was uniformly spread in a quartz boat, and heated to 400 ℃ in a muffle furnace at a heating rate of 5 ℃/min for 5 h. With the increase of the calcination temperature, carbon atoms and nitrogen atoms in Ni3[Co0.5Fe0.5(CN)6]2-PBA combine with oxygen to form CO2 and nitrogen oxide (NxOy) to escape, resulting in pores, but the framework structure of nanocubes remained unchanged. Finally, the porous Ni-Co-Fe-TMO was obtained. During this synthesis, the role of C6H5K3O7 was to control the crystal growth and nucleation rate. Similarly, the Ni3[Co(CN)6]2-PBA, Ni3[Fe(CN)6]2-PBA precursors, and their corresponding oxides Ni-Co-TMO, Ni-Fe-TMO were synthesized by the same method. For the convenience of description, the above-mentioned Ni3[Co0.5Fe0.5(CN)6]2-PBA, Ni3[Co(CN)6]2-PBA, Ni3[Fe(CN)6]2-PBA, Ni-Co-Fe-TMO, Ni-Co-TMO, and Ni-Fe-TMO are abbreviated as NCF-PBA, NC-PBA, NF-PBA, NCF-TMO, NC-TMO, and NF-TMO, respectively. 2.3 Characterization methods The morphology and crystal lattice of the catalysts were recorded by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Sigma 300) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010F). The crystal structure of the samples was obtained on X-ray Powder diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku D/Max 2400). The chemical state of the catalyst surface was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi). The Ultraviolet-visible absorption spectra were measured by UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectrometer (DRS, Shimadzu UV-3600PLUS spectrophotometer). The photoluminescence (PL) and was monitored using fluorescence spectrophotometer (FLS980) with an excitation wavelength of 380 nm. The temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 and temperature program reduction of H2 (TPR) were performed on a chemisorption analyzer (TPD, Autosorb-iQ-C). The stability of the samples at high temperature was determined by thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DCS, STA449 F3-NETZSCH 200F3). And the temperature change during the TG-DCS test was the same as the calcination temperature during sample preparation. 2.4 Photothermal catalytic reduction of CO2 experiment The photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction performance evaluation of catalysts was carried out in a stationary reactor-gas chromatography combined device (CEL-GPPCM, Beijing Zhongjiao Jinyuan Technology Co., Ltd.). The reactor was a thick quartz glass tube with an inner diameter of 60 mm. Before the photothermal reaction, a certain mass of catalyst was put into a quartz reactor containing quartz wool, and then it was installed on the reaction device. Then, CO2 was introduced into the reactor to drive out the air in the reactor. At the same time, the temperature of the reactor was increased to 200 °C with a ramping rate of 2 ℃/min. After 30 min, a 300 W Xenon lamp was turned on to irradiate the reactor. Meanwhile, CO2 and H2 were introduced into the reactor (the flow rate of both gases was 5 mL min−1) for photothermal CO2 reduction reaction. Finally, the reaction effluent gas was injected into the gas chromatograph through a six-way valve for online quantitative detection every 30 min 2.5 Photoelectrochemical tests The photocurrent and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were tested on an electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua CHI 660E, China) in an ambient environment, in which a standard three-electrode system was used with Pt plate as a counter electrode, the sample coated ITO glass as the working electrode, and an Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode. A 300 W Xe lamp was used as the light source. The electrolyte was 0.1 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution without any additives. Photocurrent responses were measured at 0.1 V during the on-off cycling of the visible-light simulator. EIS measures were carried out in the frequency range of 10−1 to 105 Hz and the AC voltage amplitude is 5 mV. 3 Results and discussion To investigate the structural changes of catalysts during the preparation process, the crystal structures of (NCF, NC, NF)-PBA and (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO were detected by XRD technique, and the results were exhibited in Fig. 1. It is clear that the strong diffraction peaks of the (NCF, NC, NF)-PBA samples could be ascribed to the cubic Ni3[Co0.5Fe0.5(CN)6]2 (PDF#96–431–8756), Ni3[Co(CN)6]2 (PDF#01–089–3738), and Ni3[Fe(CN)6]2 (PDF#00–014–0291), respectively. After calcination, the diffraction peak intensity of the three samples decreased significantly, and the position of the diffraction peaks also shows an obvious change, which indicates that the above PBAs samples have been transformed into new substances with relatively low crystallinity. By careful comparison with standard cards, it is found that Ni2+, Co2+, and Fe3+ in (NCF, NC, NF)-PBA are converted into corresponding oxides, namely rhombohedral NiO (PDF#01–089–3080), cubic Co3O4 (PDF#01–080–1533), and rhombohedral Fe2O3 (PDF#01–073–0603), respectively. Simultaneously, the (CN)6 - ions in (NCF, NC, NF)-PBA combine with O2 in the air to generate gaseous oxides and escape [43]. The above results show that we have successfully prepared Ni–Co–Fe, Ni–Co, and Ni–Fe oxides based on Prussian blue analogs by a three-step method, respectively. In order to explore whether the prepared (NCF, NC, NF)-PBA precursors have been completely transformed into the corresponding (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO after calcination, TG-DSC tests were carried out. As shown in Fig. S1, the three samples all exhibit an obvious weight-loss platform between 100 ℃ ⁓ 200 ℃, which is mainly caused by the evaporation of water molecules adsorbed on the catalysts surface. As the temperature continues to rise, the weight of the (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO catalysts remain basically unchanged between 200 ⁓ 400 ℃, indicating that the three precursors had been completely transformed into stable oxides after calcination in the muffle furnace. To better understand the morphologies of PBAs and their corresponding TMOs, the characterization data of SEM images were obtained. As given in Fig. 2, it is easy to see that the morphology of all samples is regular cubic structures. Obviously, the size of NC-PBA and NC-TMO is the largest among all the samples. The edge length of NC-TMO is around 400 nm, and the size of the other two oxides is about 200 nm. By further comparing the SEM images of the oxides with their corresponding PBA precursors, it can be found that the cubic morphology of the precursor is maintained after calcination, but the gas escape leads to a porous structure with a slightly smaller size and a rougher surface. Among them, the changes of NCF-TMO and NF-TMO are the most obvious (Fig. 1(b, f)), which means that the catalysts could have rich reactive active sites and full contact with the reaction gas, thus improving their catalytic performances. Fig. 3 displays the TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO samples. As displayed in Fig. 3(a, d, and g), it can be seen that the three oxides exhibit cubic structures with many small holes on their surface. By comparing the TEM images of oxides obtained after calcination, it is concluded that the size of NCF-TMO and NF-TMO is smaller than that of NC-TMO, which is consistent with the size changes of their corresponding PBAs. These results indicate that the addition of Fe3+ ions can reduce the size of the catalysts, thus realizing the structure regulation of the catalysts [44]. The HRTEM images of NCF-TMO exhibit three evident sets of crystallographic planes with two adjacent lattice planes distances of 2.09 Å, 2.02 Å, and 2.52 Å, which correspond well with the NiO (202), Co3O4 (400), and Fe2O3 (110) planes, respectively (as shown in Fig. 3b). Moreover, it is found that the d-spacing fringes of 2.09 Å and 2.44 Å match the NiO (202), and Co3O4 (311) planes, respectively, in the as-prepared NC-TMO (Fig. 3e). And the lattice fringes of 2.09 Å and 2.52 Å are in good agreement with the NiO (202), and Fe2O3 (110) planes, respectively, in the NF-TMO sample (Fig. 3h). In addition, the elements mapping results of (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO further illustrate their cubic structure, and the corresponding elements are uniformly distributed in the three samples, respectively (see Fig. 3(c, f, and i)). The quantitative element ratio of (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO catalysts were also measured by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). As exhibited in Table S1, the final element ratio of the three samples is basically consistent with the actual feed ratio in the process of sample preparation, indicating that the loss of Ni, Fe and Co elements can be negligible during the sample preparation process. Furthermore, the interfacial contact between NiO and Co3O4/Fe2O3 is well, which may drive the separation and transfer of electron-hole pairs, and therefore enhance the photothermal activity. These results demonstrate that the (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO have been successfully fabricated by a simple growth strategy. To obtain further insight of the surface chemical states and electronic structures of NCF-TMO, NC-TMO, and NF-TMO, XPS technique was characterized. Fig. 4(a-b) display the high-resolution XPS results of the Ni 2p, Co 2p, Fe 2p and O 1 s, respectively. In the Ni 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 4a), Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of the three samples can be fitted to two sub-peaks, respectively. The sub-peaks at the positions with higher binding energy correspond to Ni2+ 2p3/2 and Ni2+ 2p1/2, namely NiO. The sub-peaks at lower binding energy positions correspond to Ni3+ 2p3/2 and Ni3+ 2p1/2. However, the Ni3+ refers to the structure that contains Ni2+ ions with holes and not to Ni2O3 phase [45]. And compared with the NCF-TMO and NC-TMO, the peaks of Ni 2p3/2 for the NF-TMO are positively shifted. For the Co 2p spectra (Fig. 4b), the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 spectra can be indexed to the two spin-orbit components of Co3+ and Co2+, respectively. The peaks located at 779.8 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 794.8 eV (Co 2p1/2), and the signals at 781.7 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 796.4 eV (Co 2p1/2) for NCF-TMO match with the Co3+ and Co2+, respectively. Compared with the NCF-TMO, the characteristic peak position of Co3+ in NC-TMO is slightly shifted. Fig. 4(c) denotes the XPS of Fe 2p, the peaks at 711.0 eV and 724.6 eV for NCF-TMO, and the peaks at 710.9 eV and 724.2 eV for NC-TMO, agree with the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 spin-orbit doublets of Fe3+. In addition, the above three XPS spectra of Ni 2p, Co 2p, and Fe 2p are accompanied by satellite peaks (denoted as ‘Sat.’), which means that the three ions exist in the form of oxides, namely, NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3, respectively [46,47]. Moreover, in the O 1 s spectra of the three samples, the single peak at 529.9 eV or 529.8 eV in each sample can be well fitted to the metal–O (Ni–O, Co–O, and Fe–O), which are consistent with the characteristic peak analysis results of the above three metal ions. Further analysis of the peak positions for the above four ions, it can be found that the peak positions of the same ions are slightly shifted compared with each other, which indicate that there are different degrees of electronic interaction among the oxides contained in the three samples, which are conducive to the formation of heterojunctions among the oxides [48]. Fig. 5 displays the DRS results of (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO samples. Compared with NC-TMO and NF-TMO, the NCF-TMO sample has the strongest light absorption ability, covering almost the entire UV-Vis light region. In addition, the absorption edge of the NCF-TMO sample exhibits a significant redshift, which could be ascribed to the interaction of the heterojunction formed between NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3. These results indicate that the enhanced UV–Vis light absorption of the NCF-TMO can produce more photogenerated carriers that benefit the photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction. The photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction experiment was performed in a transparent quartz tubular reactor. Fig. 6 shows the photothermal conversion of CO2 over NCF-TMO, NC-TMO, and NF-TMO samples. In the absence of light irradiation and a heat source, no product was detected. In order to explore the catalytic performance of the samples under only light irradiation or only thermal radiation condition, we carried out catalytic experiments with NCF-TMO sample. As shown in Fig. 6(a), under light irradiation, the photocatalytic CO2 reduction product is only CO, and the CO yield is just about 0.020 mmol g-1 h-1. When there was only thermal radiation, the thermal catalytic products are CO and CH4, but the average yields of both are quite low, about 0.0003 mmol g-1 h-1 and 0.002 mmol g-1 h-1, respectively. These results indicate that photocatalysis alone or thermal catalysis alone can not make the NCF-TMO catalyst play an efficient CO2 reduction performance. After simultaneously adding light and heat, the products of photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction are still CO and CH4 (Fig. 6b). Clearly, it could be noted that the NCF-TMO catalyst has much higher catalytic activity, compared with its photocatalytic and thermal-catalytic performance. Therefore, we evaluated the photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction performance of NCF-TMO, NC-TMO and NF-TMO, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6(b-d), NCF-TMO showed higher CO2 reduction performance than the other two samples. Specifically, the NCF-TMO only gives 2.5 mmol g-1 h-1 of CO and 0.4 mmol g-1 h-1 of CH4 after 1 h of reaction. With the prolongation of reaction time, its activity of converting CO2 to CO remains stable, but the CH4 production activity increased significantly. When the reaction proceeded to 4.5 h, the NCF-TMO sample can give 2.9 mmol g-1 h-1 of CO and 1.6 mmol g-1 h-1 of CH4. On the contrary, for the NC-TMO catalyst, the CO production activity increases gradually before 2.5 h, but decreases slightly after 2.5 h, and the CH4 production activity remains at 1.0 mmol g-1 h-1. In the whole process of CO2 reduction, the catalytic activity of NC-TMO is always lower than that of NCF-TMO. And the NF-TMO has the lowest photothermal catalytic performance among the three samples. This suggests that, compared with the composites of NiO and Co3O4, and NiO and Fe2O3, the combination of NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3 may better separate electrons and holes, thereby promoting the catalytic performance of NCF-TMO sample. Besides, the catalytic activity of NCF-TMO was compared with other catalysts reported in the literatures. As shown in Table S2, the NCF-TMO shows relatively higher CO2 reduction activity than most reported values. Photothermal conversion of CO2 over (b) NCF-TMO, (c) NC-TMO, (d) NF-TMO. Reaction condition: Catalyst, 0.35 g; Light source; 300 W Xenon lamp; Reaction temperature: 200 ℃; H2/CO2 flow rates: 5.0 mL min−1/5.0 mL min−1. In order to analyze whether the catalysts themselves are affected during the CO2 reduction reaction, H2-TPR measurement was used. As shown in Fig. S2, there are 2–3 reduction peaks in the 200 ⁓ 700 ℃ temperature range for each sample, and no reduction peak appeared at 200 ℃. Therefore, it can be inferred that the hydrogen consumed at 200 ℃ is used for CO2 reduction, not to reduce the three catalysts. Furthermore, the photothermal catalytic stability of NCF-TMO was checked. As shown in Fig. 7(a) The NCF-TMO exhibits excellent stability after 12.5 h. The CO and CH4 production at 12.5 h is 2.98 and 1.48 mmol h-1 g-1, respectively. In addition, we obtained the XRD pattern and SEM image of the as-prepared NCF-TMO after photothermal catalysis. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the structure and morphology of the NCF-TMO after photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction are well maintained compared with those before photothermal catalysis, indicating the good stability of the present catalyst. Obviously, this is essential for the practical application of NCF-TMO in photothermal CO2 reduction. In order to verify whether the (NCF, NC, NF)-TMO catalysts had chemical interaction with the adsorbed reaction substrates, these catalysts were characterized by CO2-TPD. Fig. 8(a) is a comparison of the CO2-TPD profiles of the above three samples after hydrogen pretreatment, in which the peak areas represent the amount of CO2 molecules adsorbed by the catalyst, and the peak positions represent the type of adsorption center possessed by the catalysts. The appearance of these peaks may result from the porous structure of the samples, which promotes the adsorption of CO2 molecules. As shown in Fig. 8(b-d), it can be found that there are four types of desorption peaks in the three catalysts. Specifically, the two desorption peaks in the low-temperature regions appear in the range of 50 ℃∼170 ℃ and 170 ℃∼350 ℃, respectively. And the other two desorption peaks in the high-temperature regions appear in the temperature range of 350 ℃∼520 ℃ and 520 ℃∼800 ℃, respectively. The desorption peak in the low-temperature regions can be attributed to the physical adsorption process of CO2 molecules by the catalysts, and the force is weak, which belongs to van der Waals force adsorption. The desorption peaks in the high-temperature regions represent the strong interaction force between catalysts and CO2, which belong to the chemisorption process [49,50]. Compared with the other three types of peaks, there is a relatively large desorption peak area in the temperature range of 170 ℃∼350 ℃, which means that this temperature range contains the real reaction temperature of the photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction reaction. Moreover, the peak area of NCF-TMO located in this region is larger than that of the other two samples. This result indicates that there are a large number of active adsorption centers for the NCF-TMO catalyst in this temperature range, which is conducive to the CO2 reduction reaction. Further compared with the other two samples, the desorption peak area of NCF-TMO in the high-temperature region (170 ℃∼350 ℃) increases significantly and the peak position (266.3 ℃) shifts slightly to the low-temperature region, which indicate that the composites of NiO, Co3O4, and Fe2O3 in NCF-TMO can obviously promote the chemisorption of CO2, thereby increasing the activity of NCF-TMO samples for photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction. To reveal the photoexcited electron transfer process, the transient photocurrent and EIS of the samples were conducted ( Fig. 9(a-b)). Obviously, the photocurrent of NCF-TMO is greatly increased compared with that of the other two samples (Fig. 9a). Proverbially, the photocurrent is generated by the directional migration of photoexcited electrons to the photocathode and synchronously holes are consumed at the photoanode, the significantly increased photocurrent intensity over the NCF-TMO indicates the more effective separation of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs and a longer lifetime of the photoinduced charge carriers than that of other samples, which are conducive to the catalytic performance improvement [51]. Fig. 9(b) shows the EIS Nyquist plots of three catalysts, and the corresponding spectra shapes of all samples are semicircular. In the Nyquist plots, the NCF-TMO sample exhibits the smallest semicircle compared with NC-TMO and NF-TMO. Clearly, the combination of NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3 leads to a notably decreased impedance, suggesting a fast carrier transfer rate in NCF-TMO [52]. PL spectra can offer the information on trapping, transfer, and annihilation dynamics of photoinduced electron-hole pairs, so it was conducted to further reveal the catalytic process [53]. The weak PL intensity means a high separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs and preeminent catalytic activity. Fig. 9(c) shows the PL spectra of three samples. In this case, it is obvious that NCF-TMO shows a significantly faster quenching of PL in comparison with that of NC-TMO and NF-TMO, meaning the electron-hole pairs recombination of NCF-TMO can be efficiently prohibited by the junction between NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3. To quantitatively study the photogenerated electron transfer process in TMO, the TRPL spectroscopy measurement was employed. As given in Fig. 9(d), the average lifetime of the electrons is calculated by fitting the data using the following equation [54]: τ = A 1 τ 1 2 + A 2 τ 2 2 A 1 τ 1 + A 2 τ 2 where < τ > represents the average lifetime, Ai and τi mean the amplitude and the decay time of the individual component, respectively. Two exponential terms of photoluminescence lifetime are obtained by fitting the decay curves (see the inset Table in Fig. 9d). Obviously, the average lifetime of NCF-TMO, NC-TMO and NF-TMO are 5.127, 4.251 and 3.148 ns, respectively. Obviously, the < τ > of NCF-TMO is the longest among the three catalysts. These results consistently demonstate the NCF-TMO sample is more favorable to electron transfer. On the basis of the above analysis, a possible mechanism of photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction to CO and CH4 over NCF-TMO, NC-TMO, and NF-TMO is proposed. After investigating the literatures [55–57], the band edge positions of NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3 are shown in Scheme 2. As shown in Scheme 2(a), NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3 in NCF-TMO sample are excited by the light and heat to form e--h+ pairs. Driven by the difference in the band edge positions of the three oxides and the formation of heterojunctions, the interface transport of carriers in the three oxides is caused as follows: (ⅰ) The electrons located in the conduction band (CB) of Co3O4 transfer to the CB of NiO; (ⅱ) The holes in the valence band (VB) of NiO migrate to the VB of Fe2O3; (ⅲ) The electrons in the CB of Fe2O3 jump to the VB of Co3O4. Thus, the transfer paths of the three carriers mentioned above significantly promote the rapid separation of e--h+ pairs. Then, the H2 molecules are oxidized to hydrogen protons (H+) by h+ that gathered on the VB of Fe2O3. And the CO2 and H+ adsorbed are reduced to CO and CH4 by e- in the CB of NiO. However, for the NC-TMO, the excited e- located in the CB of Co3O4 is firstly moved to the CB of NiO, and the excited h+ in the VB of NiO is transferred to the VB of Co3O4, forming a typical type-Ⅱ heterojunction. Secondly, the H2 molecules are oxidized to H+ by h+ in the VB of Co3O4. Simultaneously, the CO2 and H+ adsorbed are reduced to CO and CH4 by h+ in the e- in the CB of NiO (Scheme 2b). For the NF-TMO, only the h+ in VB of NiO is excited and migrates to the VB of Fe2O3. And then the e- in the CB of NiO and the h+ in the VB of Fe2O3 participate in the CO2 reduction of and H2O oxidation, respectively (Scheme 2c). Compared with the NCF-TMO, the formation and separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs in NC-TMO and NF-TMO are significantly reduced, so their catalytic activity is also much lower than that of NCF-TMO. 4 Conclusion In summary, the NCF-PBA, NC-PBA, and NF-PBA precursors were obtained by co-precipitation method, and then calcined in air to obtain PBAs-derived oxides: NCF-TMO, NC-TMO, and NF-TMO. According to XRD and SEM analysis, it can be concluded that the crystallinity of PBAs decreases obviously after calcination to form TMO, but they still maintain the cubic morphology. Interestingly, these TMOs exhibit porous cubes due to the escape of CO2 and NxOy gas during the calcination process, which may be conducive to their full contact with CO2 and H2 molecules in the photothermal catalysis, thus improving their catalytic activity. Combined with XRD and TEM results, TMOs are mainly composed of corresponding NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3. Furthermore, from the XPS discussion, it can be inferred that the three TMOs have close interfacial contact by the oxides they contain to form heterojunctions. Take NCF-TMO for example, it is found that heterojunctions are formed between NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3. In the performance evaluation section, all three oxides show photothermal activity for CO2 reduction, among which NCF-TMO has the best catalytic activity. Under the same reaction conditions, NCF-TMO can efficiently reduce CO2 to CO (2.9 mmol g-1 h-1) and CH4 (1.6 mmol g-1 h-1), and shows superior catalytic stability and structural stability. To gain deeper insight into the enhancement mechanism behind it, further analysis of the catalyst was carried out. TPD results indicate that there are a large number of active sites involved in the NCF-TMO catalyst at the given temperature. In the meantime, NCF-TMO presents more enhanced UV–Vis light absorption, higher photocurrent, lower impedance, and a longer excited charges lifetime than those of NC-TMO and NF-TMO, which is expected as a better chance for participating in redox reactions rather than recombining. Finally, combined with the mechanism analysis, it is found that efficient electron-hole pairs separation occurs in NCF-TMO under photothermal stimulation, which greatly improves its catalytic activity. The results of this work provide a reference for the development of an efficient catalytic system for photothermal CO2 hydrogenation to fuel synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction is an attractive way to alleviate the current energy crisis, but it is important to prepare catalysts with efficient catalytic capacity. In this work, Prussian blue analogs were firstly prepared, and then calcined to obtain porous transition metal (Ni, Co, Fe) oxides (TMOs). The metal composition of catalysts has great influences on their structures and catalytic properties. Among them, NCF-TMO catalyst shows excellent photothermal catalytic performance, and can produce 2.9 mmol g-1 h-1 CO and 1.6 mmol g-1 h-1 mmol CH4 at low CO2 and H2 concentrations. For the NCF-TMO, its superior catalytic performance mainly benefitted from two reasons: (1) The construction of heterojunction between NiO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3, which promotes the efficient dynamic processes of charge carriers; (2) The formation of abundant surface reactive active sites facilitates the efficient conversion of CO2 molecules. This study offers a bright direction for the resource utilization of CO2.
coredata.dc:title: Ternary Ni–Co–Fe oxides based on Prussian blue analog for efficient photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction to CO and CH4
